sub_title: Scout Missions System Manager at European Space Agency - ESA
summary:
An innovative technical leader and project manager with a highly successful record of accomplishments in the space industry

Massimiliano Pastena has twenty years of experience in space system developments with over ten years of leadership experience within the space hardware development and deployment field. In this time he has had the opportunity to work on numerous projects and publications in a variety of specialities to include development of re-entry vehicle and related technologies, as well as Mission and Spacecraft design and deployment. He has extensive experience in project and engineering management as well as new technologies development.

TECHNICAL LEADER with expertise in technical supervision of all jobs including missions, new equipment, new technologies and systems development and standard product improvement.

EXCELS AT PROJECT MANAGEMENT, with extensive experience managing national and international programs with budgets up to 40 M€, and deriving the project requirements and constraints from the mission statement.

PROVEN ABILITY TO translate the proposal of the Prime Scientific Investigator, as well as customer requirements, into Engineering and Technological Solutions, in addition to verifying the feasibility and effectiveness of the solutions.

DEMONSTRATES INNOVATIVE DESIGN TECHNIQUES, in the development of various complex hardware and software for applications in space.

CORE PROFESSIONAL ABILITIES

 Program/Project Management  Collaborative Networking       Exceptional Communicator
 Motivational Supervision           Organizational Management  Staff Development and Mentoring
 High-Impact Decision Making   Superb Time Management     Strategic Planning Initiatives

Specialties: Space mission (ground and space segments) design and development specialization in earth observation LEO mission.
Re-entry and unmanned vehicle design and development.
GNC and AOCS system and equipment design and development

projects.title: LFCP
projects.description: LFCP is a GSTP project financed by the European Space Agency (ESA) aimed to develop the EM of an on board payload data processor based on a Leon 3 processor board enhanced by a FFT coprocessor

projects.title: 26PropagSAT
projects.description: 26PropagSAT mission main goal is to fill the gap in knowledge and experimental data in the transmission in the band between 25.5GHz and 27GHz focusing in particular on the study of the propagation of the 26 GHz signal from space to a high latitude ground station. In addition the study gave the possibility to define a new concept of cubesat, under development in SSBV Aerospace & Technology Group. The proposed spacecraft bus while based on a standard 3U form factor cubesat platform, represents a step forward in terms of reliability, redundancy, architecture, communication busses and standard protocol It represents a movement toward operative cubesat missions with respect to the current low cost missions featuring use of low reliability parts and operating in the amateur radio bands

projects.title: Ldorado
projects.description:
L-Dorado is a highly performant cubesat mission that has direct commercial application potential.
The primary mission will continuously monitor L-Band RF emissions from an orbital platform. A wide range of commercial applications as well as a number of scientific capabilities have been researched.
The basic operation mode of the system, which will be implemented in the commissioning phase of the mission, will be to capture a number of orbits of RF data to build up a library of emissions which can be used to populate a database. The emission frequencies can be chosen across the entire L-Band spectrum. The anticipation is that organisations will develop novel applications built on this data. For example, it is known that the missions (working in the L- band 1.4 to 1.43GHz) is having its science degraded by accidental or illegal transmissions in this protected band. An RF transmission database in this frequency range could be use to indicate data quality as well as the possibility of identifying the transmitters and requesting them to be switched off. Similar maps could be created for the navigation bands (GPS L1 at 1.575.42MHz for example).
Once the initial commissioning is complete, L-Dorado will become an in-orbit RF test bed for applications developers.

projects.title: CubeSat Sun Sensor
projects.description:
The CubeSat sun sensor determines the spacecraft body angles with respect to the sun. The sensor is extremely small and light to minimise the demands on nano-spacecraft. The sensor achieves much higher measurement accuracy than traditional photodiode cosine sensors.

The sensor consists of a CMOS PSD detector sitting behind a small pin-hole with a field of view of +/- 57 degrees. The device produces four analogue voltages that are dependant on the incident angle of sunlight in the horizontal and vertical directions. Each sensor is supplied with a calibration algorithm that calculates the sun vector from these four voltages to an accuracy of +/-0.5 degrees

projects.title: Magnetometer
projects.description:
The design of the tri-axial magnetometer utilises Anisotropic Magneto-Resistance (AMR). The sensors are implemented as ceramic packages and co-located with drive electronics in a potted sensor head – ideally at the end of a rigid boom. Closed loop control improves the overall linearity and limits sensitivity drift.

The MR driver ensures the sensor maintains low noise operation by holding the sensor at its optimum position on the sensor transfer function. The sensors delivers the three components of the magnetics field plus a temperature measurement.

In CubeSat applications the magnetometer requires an electronics mezzanine card one third the area of a standard CubeSat PCB. The sensors connects to the mezzanine via a lightweight harness. Power requirements are one digital (3.3 or 5V) and one analogue (12V-15V) line. A digital serial interface can be included if required. In microsat applications, the additional electronics is integrated with the sensor head resulting in a very compact unit that is simple to accommodate.

projects.title: HAGRID
projects.description: HAGRID (Heliospheric imaging for Assessment of Global and Regional Infrastructure Damage) is a mission concept carried out in the RAL Space Concurrent Design Facility in early 2011. HAGRID is a novel space weather alert mission using a single spacecraft located at the L4 Lagrangian point to provide real time alerts of impending space weather events triggered by Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) and Co-rotating Interaction Regions (CIR) arriving at the Earth's magnetosphere.

projects.title: Cubesat Magnetorquer Rod
projects.description:
The use of a magnetic alloy rod produces an amplification effect over an air cored magnetorquer. This allows a system that uses less power, which is critical for CubeSat missions. The rods can enable a mission with increased manoeuvrability and reduced detumble rates.

CubeSat Magnetorquer rods are designed to be run directly from a switched 5 Volt power output from the on-board power control system.

projects.title: Adaheli
projects.description: ADAHELI Mission investigate the Sun's photospheric and chromospheric dynamics by performing observations in VIS-NIR bands and solar irradiance by acquisitions in the millimetric bands

projects.title: MIOSAT
projects.description: MIOSat is a LEO microsatellite of ~ 120 kg with the objective to fly three innovative optical payloads: a) Sagnac interferometer, b) Mach Zehnder interferometer, and c) a high resolution panchromatic camera with a deployable telescope. In addition three technological experiment will be tested on-orbit.

projects.title: Demise Observation Capsule (DOC)
projects.description:
The DOC is a project for the design, development and manufacturing of the new Demise Observation Capsule (DOC), meant to help better understand what occurs to space debris during re-entry towards Earth, in particular launcher stages. Collection and analysis of the re-entry data about objects re-entering the atmosphere will help in accurately predicting break-up altitudes, debris trajectories and ground impact footprint. These analyses are therefore critical not only to mission success, but more importantly for improving public safety aspects of such re-entry scenarios. 
As part of the Future Launchers Preparatory Programme (FLPP), the DOC will study re-entry phenomena by attaching a capsule and sensors to a launch vehicle.

projects.title: PanelSAR
projects.description: PanelSAR is a project aimed to develop the first FMCW SAR in space. Thanks to its low power consumption PanelSAR is suitable for small satellite application and due to its low budget represent a constellation enabler increasing the availability of the information maintaining an image quality as good as pulsed SAR

projects.title: CubeSat ACS board
projects.description: A CubeSat Attitude Control System (ACS) measures orbit position, absolute attitude, spacecraft rates and can also control the orientation of the satellite through either magnetic actuation or wheel based solutions. The  ACS board is a single PC104 board (15mm height) that physically integrates three high accuracy sun sensors, a magnetometer, MEMS gyros, a stellar gyro and two magnetorquer rods. Additionally, external interfaces allow for a further three sun sensors, the Z-axis magnetorquer as well as momentum or reaction wheels.

projects.title: Orbcomm second Generation Reaction wheel
projects.description: Supply of Reaction Wheels for the Orbcomm second generation constellation. Orbcomm is a constellation for narrow band two-way digital messaging with a World wide coverage from Sierra Nevada Corporation

projects.title: ESEO
projects.description: European satellite for Earth observation developed by European universities with Carlo Gavazzi Space as Prime toward ESA

projects.title: ARGO (Formosat-5) CDMU
projects.description: Design and development of next generation of on board computer (CDMU) in collaboration with ACER in the framework of former ARGO now formosat 5, the first satellite developed by the Taiwanese National Space Organization (NSPO) for Earth observation with the consultancy support of Carlo Gavazzi Space and STI

projects.title: USV the CIRA Unmanned Space Vehicle
projects.description: USV is a flying laboratories performing re entry missions during which the accommodated payloads could experiment and/or validate re entry strategies, technologies, equipment, analyses and theory.

projects.title: VEGA
projects.description: Vega is a small single-body launcher with three solid-propellant stages and a liquid-propellant upper module for attitude and orbit control, and satellite release. Unlike most small launchers, Vega is able to place multiple payloads into orbit.

projects.title: LISA inertial sensor
projects.description: The project was aimed at developing the Engineering Model of the LISA Inertial Sensor Demonstrator to be flown as ESA LISA Pathfinder mission payload
